instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.PBUS_G3H: What is PBUS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PBUS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3_OUT: What is PPVRTC_G3_OUT? PPVRTC_G3_OUT is a 3.3v power line that comes out of the clock chip. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>. ok
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. ok
<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL>  not stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>. ok
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing
<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12 v ok

all other voltages after 3v3 s5 also just pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Remove F7040 and check again mentioned voltages.

Also check diode mode to ground on all big coils.
Compare with good board, if available.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Removed  F7040
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> -present okey
resistance ground on coils found good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
when  I removed coil L7100
all stable 
excluding core 
I think VCCSAS0 may be short or something.
what may be the issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Looks like CPU issue.
VCCSA must appear before VCORE.

Resolder L7100 and remove <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR>.
Test the board again; VCCSA should be stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
no
removed  <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR> still not stable
voltage trips only while switching vacs

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Test starting in SMC bypass too.

You may have a problem with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, or adiacent components.
Post its basic voltages; pins 19, 20, 15.
Check diode mode to ground at L7100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
diode mode to ground at L7100 -0.030v
ohms mode to ground at L7100- 29 ohms
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> already changed
also changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7100</TRANSISTOR>
basic voltages; pins 19, 20, 15. cycling 5v,5v,3.3v respectively.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
removed <RESISTOR>R7987</RESISTOR> 
VCCSA  ,VCORE both not switching because I removed vccsa enable
all other before vccsa remains stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 99172, member: 682"]
Test starting in SMC bypass too.

You may have a problem with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, or adiacent components.
Post its basic voltages; pins 19, 20, 15.

[/QUOTE]

I think you are saying some stupid things or you are wasting my time.
I already said that the VCCSAS0 voltage comes up, after which all voltages drop down and repeats
So what is the requirement behind checking <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 19,20 and15

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
"all other voltages after 3v3 s5 also just pulsing"
Including CPU VCORE?

If other voltages are stable disabling VCCSA and nothing wrong with its power supply, then bad CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Including CPU VCORE?  no
until vccsa

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
I found a strange issue 
am getting all voltages stable including VCCSA (but no VCORE and no CPUVCCIO ) When unscrewing one of the screw nearby cooling fan in the heat sink

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC PM G2 EN  pulsing
threads.message:
Really strange, VCCIO should appear before VCCSA.
Not even pulse at L7630?

The reaction after unscrewing part of heatsink, may denote broken solder, or trace.
